The Soyuz doesn't have twenty engines in it's first stage, it has five. The four boosters are powered by a single RD-117 engine, a variant of the RD-107 engine with twin S1.358000 steerable Vernier thrusters, while the center stage is powered by a single RD-118 engine, a variant of the RD-108 engine with four S1.358000 steerable Vernier thrusters. Even though it looks like there are twenty, there are only five because each of the five engines is multi-chambered and running off a single turbopump.

I hate to be pedantic, but the Soyuz rocket family ignites only five engines at liftoff. The RD-107 engine family uses one turbo pump to power four fixed thrust chambers and two or four single-plane verniers. These engines were designed with rugged simplicity in mind.

I understand what you're trying to say, but the first stage ignition of a Falcon Heavy is far more complex than the first stage ignition of a Soyuz rocket because you're dealing with 22 more turbo pumps on engines that are designed to be throttleable, recoverable, and reusable. Soyuz has five that run only at 100% throttle and are done at engine cutoff.

Interestingly, the NK-15 that propelled the N-1's ill-fated flights would later be developed into the NK-33/NK-43 series.  This is the series of engines that propels the Soyuz 2-1v (NK-33A) and the first version of Orbital Sciences/Orbital ATK's Antares (AJ26-58, original-production NK-33s upgraded and refurbished by Aerojet). So anyway...The way I see it, if the Space Shuttle--which was something radically different than anything that had ever been launched before, and which was built during a time when computer physics modeling was extremely primitive compared to today--worked the very first time, than there's really no reason that the FH shouldn't be expected to work. Sure, maybe not all the boosters will make flawless landings, but I see no reason why it shouldn't be completely successful in terms of putting its Roadster payload where it's supposed to put it.

Plus, engineers had enough confidence in the Space Shuttle to put humans on it on its very first launch. Granted, they kind of had to, but still...

So, I expect it to work and will be fairly crushed if it doesn't. I mean, I could live with the boosters not all making successful landings, but if it explodes, or the boosters fail to separate, or the upper stage goes rogue, I'll be crushed. SOYUZ has technically 5 booster stage ENGINES (RD-108 main engine and one RD-107 per each of the 4 strap-on liquid fuel boosters, all LOX/Kerosene), but each engine uses 4 combustion CHAMBERS. The RD-107 has an additional two vernier combustion chambers that can thrust vector in a single plane to supply attitude control. The RD-108 has four of such vernier combustion chambers to supply full vector control to the Blok-A stage.

It's insanely hard, if not impossible to model the interactions of the shock waves in between the 3 cores and how they affect the structure, and each other. It mostly depends on how robust the ignition is for each engine, if they can all light off as they should, and depends on the structures of the first stages, whether they can withstand the loads. I'm sure that SpaceX has done their best to model all of it, and have probably over built the attaching structures in hopes that it will hold together long enough to get good data on shock waves, and aerodynamic load interactions. Even if it blows up soon after liftoff, it will be valuable to get the data, and I doubt they will blow up more than a couple of them in the DEV process. I'm sure they have it wired to the hilt with telemetry, and sensors, to maximize data collection for this flight.  Will be exciting to see the launch, no matter what.  I'm also suspicious that it will be successful, as they have had lots of time to try to get the modeling right, and they can over-build it, to try and get the data for the first flight, then start shaving off mass in successive flights. I got a bit carried away writing this for another forum, but since your video inspired me to do the research, perhaps it's of interest here:-

I recently worked out SpaceX booster numbering system.... so this is an interesting addition to the info in the video.

It's an internal numbering system for all boosters (not just Falcon 9) that SpaceX build so that they can track them, through testing, flight, recovery, refurbishment etc.

Simply a B, followed by the stage number, (1 for first stage), then a 3 digit serial number. Which may be followed by a decimal point for each launch to clarify which usage... so B1021.2 would be the second flight of first stage booster 21.

The Falcon 9 has seen major upgrades twice, has hinted in this video, and the comment that Falcon Heavy was not needed due to those upgrades..... with the latest version (1.2) being the final version.

There are however, "minor" tweaks to the 1.2 version rocket, which are designated Block 1-5, with block 5 apparently being the final update before work switches to BFR.

The first F9 v1.2 booster was B1019, so this was block 1, however it's very unclear when the switch to block 2 was made.

B1029 was the first "block 3" booster, and B1039 the first "block 4" version.

The last core made is B1045, which is also "block 4", so no "block 5" boosters have been made to date.

Falcon Heavy is constructed from the only as yet un-flown "block 3" core, and 2 earlier recovered boosters which come from the "unknown" early period. so may be either "block 2 or block 3".

It's interesting that SpaceX have recently announced that they will not try to fly any "block 3" boosters more than twice... which means that they have 1 more remaining, and I predict that when it comes to launching the PZA/Starlink payload on B1038 at the end of January, they will not attempt to recover the booster.

After that the only remaining flight worthy "block 3" booster if B1035, which has already flown twice, so will probably be stripped for parts and scrapped.

Falcon Heavy is a wildcard since it is built with block 2/3 boosters which might otherwise never fly, but only the centre core is significantly modified, and since this will be it's first flight, you might well see a second flight of the same "Falcon Heavy", and I would guess they would build a new "block 5" core for commercial flights of "Falcon Heavy", using at least "block 4" side boosters.

I also think the "too many boosters" meme is a bit over-stated.... since there are actually only 12 active cores, plus 11 retired ones some of which are being used for destructive testing or being displayed at museums etc.... and after January, the number of active boosters will drop to 8 or 9 depending on the outcome of the FH test... and all of those will be "block 4".

With 2 boosters on the side the additional stress on the center booster would rip it apart, so a new 'strengthened' center 1st stage had to be designed and built.   The cross-feed design turned out to be a nightmare, so they are now just going to turn off / throttle-down the center stage a few seconds into the flight, thus conserving the fuel inside that stage.  A slightly less efficient design but one with far less potential problems.   Big potential problem:  if an engine fails in one of the outboard stages, the resulting off-center thrust will be too large for the navigational controls to handle via engine vectoring alone,  and the entire rocket will slide sideways resulting in a breakup.  The design team will need to add in a quick counter-engine-shutoff into their navigational control programming to deal with such an event should it occur.  so lets say an engine 'pops' in the left stage;  well then, an engine in the right stage will be shut off half a second later, thus preserving thrust stability.

Good video but a few addons and corrections:

The crossfeed in Falcon Heavy was never intended to top up the center core tanks, but to directly feed the the 2x3 side engines of the original thrust structure, like the Shuttle external tank fed Shuttle's engines. The center 3 engines were to be fed by the center core tanks itself. The fuel pumps needed to make KSP-like crossfeed aren't realistic at all.

Another main source for the FH delays was due to SpaceX having to requalify a lot of components especially for it. Three times more engines firing together creates a much harsher acoustic environment, for example.

The Souyuz shown in the photo has 5 engines plus 12 vernier thrusters for maneuvering, not 20 engines. Each of the main engines has 4 combustion chambers and nozzles.

I used to be more sceptical about FH's first launch (exactly because we know what happened to N1), but over the last years they have racked up such a great track record when it comes to the performance of the Merlin engines. They're very reliable and have shown they can be reused and relit over and over. So I don't expect a failure of the engines. If anything, my bet is on either excessive MaxQ stress or a side core separation failure. These are much more likely causes for (partial) failures. All in all I think I cautiously share your optimism for a complete success. And if FH blows up on it's demo flight, at least it'll be good data!

Also, I think we can expect a late January, early February launch date for FH. Anyways, I'll surely be watching and cheering for the guys and gals at SpaceX, as I always have :D
